comments_since_last_sample.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.
Didn't talk to my brother for a couple months, one day I get that choice removed. Now I wish I could go back. Don't let life distract you from those you care about.

Seriously, my dad had a stroke in his sleep one night 10 years ago and never woke up. The number of times I go back and wish I could've said what he meant to me still absolutely haunts me, don't ever let stuff like that hang in the air if you have the opportunity not to

I struggle with this all the time. Whenever I'm leaving the house my middle child wants to say bye 1000 times and get 1000 kisses that I end up annoyed. I know that's awful and if something happens to me her last memory shouldn't be of me annoyed with her.
Honestly, I’m not okay with this manipulative tactic being ingrained into everyone’s heads and making them feel guilty for being rightfully upset by things.
I told my father I loved him 8 hours before I found him dead. This is real shit.

Yup. I made sure to end every phone call/visit with my grandfather by saying “I love you, stay out of trouble.” It became an inside joke because he had Parkinson’s and eventually couldn’t get around, much less get into much trouble, but it made us both laugh so we weren’t sad and it kept us from wondering when we’d see/talk to each other again. He died last January, but at least I know that the last thing I said to him was something meaningful that made us both smile.
Don't remember the last time I saw my brother

The last thing you say to a loved one is not necessarily significant, especially if you don't know it's going to be the last thing. 

Repeating some mantra upon parting doesn't show that you care, it shows that you are preoccupied about death, loss, and guilt.
The last thing my late wife said to me before she died was "I'm really gunna miss you".  It's been 8+ years and I still miss her every single day.

My mother died about 12 hours after suffering a massive stroke. My family gathered and we took turns touching her and talking. That evening I laid on the bed with her and hugged  her and whispered, “I love you and I’ll miss you for the rest of my life, you crazy bitch.” She took her last breath less than 2 minutes later.  Some people would think that’s awful, but if she heard me she went out laughing.
Isn't this just "Say nice things to your loved ones."?  And isn't that an obvious point to make?
I always do this

LOL, I got in this habit when I was was 10 out of abject paranoia that if something happened to a family member that I would be blamed because I didn't love them enough. The logic chains of a 5th grader are wacky indeed.

As somebody who has gone through this, it doesn't fucking matter. My friend still killed himself one way or the other. Does the fact that the last words I ever said to him were "I love you, bro" mak it any easier? For me, no. Because that doesn't reach to the heart of things. Freeing yourself from guilt is much more than making sure your last words are nice. I mean I try to do it, but it's because I like making people feel good.

never really understood that. isn't a relationship built on all that happens over time?, how can a final statement mean anything at all!  grow up! It is statements like this that MAKE people fell bad if their last words were not the very best! (but likely deserved to be said)

Yep. 

When I was 8, my great grandmother died. She lived next to us in a small house on the property. I would play at her house every day. I remeber my last words to her.

" Don't dump my cup, I'll be back for it! " 

I didn't come back and she died the next day. 

It's sat with me ever since. It's not bad really and I was very young but there is still a bit of guilt that sits in my heart.
Almost every night I tell my mom I love her before I turn in for bed. I'll shoot my siblings and their kids a 'GN' and 'ILYA' (I love you all..) in the family group chat.
“I love you but don’t light that ma…”

This hits home. I spent an entire week with my dad and also told him multiple times how much I love him and how good of a father he is, all before he was sent to the ICU after a freak accident occurred on his birthday. You never know what can happen, so hold the people that you consider the most important close to you and don’t ever let them forget that they are your world.
For me this is true. Even though my mum was emotionally manipulative the last time I saw her I made a not nice comment. It's destroyed me since.

Narcissistic parents showing up at my doorstep unannounced after gaslighting me for helping a sibling in need who was having thoughts of self harm.



LOVE YA!



In all seriousness, I think this is generally good advice, but for me personally, it doesn't apply. I can hold my head high knowing I haven't said anything I regret to my parents and if they were to pass tomorrow, I'd mourn them but have no regrets 🤷.

*Dad leaving after another belt lesson*

LOVE YA!
